articles.title: The uphill battle ahead: Four different leaders, four different takes on global warming
articles.author: SETH BORENSTEIN
articles.summary: There are four men with vastly different visions and experiences on climate change. They are: John Kerry, Roberta Kagan, Bill McKibben and Roberta Schmitz. They all have different views and experiences about climate change and need to work together on it.

articles.title: Daylight saving starts in October for most of Australia, here's what you need to know
articles.author: Molly Magennis
articles.summary: Clocks will go forward by one hour on Sunday, October 5 at 2 am local time in NSW, Victoria, ACT, Tasmania and South Australia. The first Sunday of October marks the return of Daylight Saving Time (DST). Five out of eight Australian states and territories follow DST. DST will end on April 5, 2026. Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory do not have daylight saving.

articles.title: WA news LIVE: Warning for Perth drivers as double demerits kick in
articles.summary: Double demerits are in place for the long weekend, and they will be out in force over the next two weeks for school holidays. There have been 137 deaths on WA roads this year, outstripping last year's figures by 5%. The state is approaching one of its worst road tolls in 10 years. James Comey has been indicted on criminal charges of false statements and obstruction.

articles.title: WA news LIVE: Warning for Perth drivers as double demerits kick in
articles.summary: Double demerits are in place for the long weekend, and they will be out in force over the next two weeks for school holidays. There have been 137 deaths on WA roads this year, outstripping last year's figures by 5%. The state is approaching one of its worst road tolls in 10 years. James Comey has been indicted on criminal charges of false statements and obstruction.

articles.title: Rare, sudden weather event to bring chaos for Australia
articles.summary: A rare stratospheric warming event over the Antarctic this week is expected to bring chaotic spring to Australia's south and a drier than average season to the nation's east. The polar vortex is weakening and cold air circling around the Antarctic is being dragged away by the southern hemisphere's polar jet stream.

articles.title: Rare event to bring chaos for Australia
articles.author: Hannah Moore
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming event over the Antarctic this week is expected to bring chaotic spring to Australia's south and a drier than average season to the nation's east. Temperatures high above Antarctica have risen by more than 30C. Since 2002, the only other sudden major warming event was in 2019, which preceded historic deadly bushfires.

articles.title: ‘Life and death': Wong's nuclear AI warning
articles.summary: Nuclear weapons could be fired by artificial intelligence, Australia's Foreign Affairs Minister has warned the United Nations.  “Artificial intelligence could be used to fire nuclear weapons,” he warned the UN. “It's a real possibility.”

articles.title: The Wildlife Trusts: Nature being hit by 'frightening pace' of climate change
articles.author: Archie Struthers
articles.summary: Wildlife and nature have borne the brunt of extreme shifts in weather patterns and the "frightening pace" of climate change over the past year, according to a new report by The Wildlife Trusts. The Roaches in Staffordshire was destroyed by a wildfire.

articles.title: Nature battered by ‘chaotic' weather extremes driven by climate change
articles.author: Emily Beament
articles.summary: In the past year, the UK has seen extreme weather patterns driven by climate change. The Wildlife Trusts warn that the country is 'shockingly underprepared' for the kind of extremes we are now seeing. The Trusts are taking steps to protect nature and make landscapes more resilient to the changes.

articles.title: Twiggy slams Trump 'bulldust' on climate change
articles.summary: Billionaire Andrew "Twiggy" Forrest has slammed US President Donald Trump's stance on climate change in a new interview with National Geographic magazine.   .       "I am not a supporter of Donald Trump on climate policy."

articles.title: Sudden stratospheric warming to shift Australia's spring forecast
articles.author: Hannah Moore
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming event over the Antarctic this week is expected to bring chaotic spring to Australia's south and a drier than average season to the nation's east. Temperatures high above Antarctica have risen by more than 30C and the polar vortex is weakening. It could mean more rain and westerly winds for southern Australia and abnormally hot days in southern Australia.

articles.title: Rare Antarctic weather event sparks spring chaos warning for Australia
articles.author: Hannah Moore
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming event over the Antarctic this week is expected to bring a chaotic spring to Australia's south and a drier than average season to the nation's east. It has led to temperatures high above Antarctica climbing by more than 30C. Since 2002, the only other sudden major warming event was in 2019, which preceded historic deadly bushfires.

articles.title: Sudden stratospheric warming to shift Australia's spring forecast
articles.author: Hannah Moore
articles.summary: Sudden stratospheric warming event over the Antarctic this week is expected to bring a chaotic spring to Australia's south and a drier than average season to the nation's east. It has led to temperatures high above Antarctica climbing by more than 30C. It is common in the northern hemisphere, occurring every two years on average but less frequent in the south.

articles.title: Cooler temperatures to come but at different times in different U.S. cities
articles.author: Ade Adeniji
articles.summary: On average, New York City's last 80-degree day comes in early October. Seattle's warmest month is August, with average highs around 77.6 F. Los Angeles has warm, dry summers with long days, but cold nights and rainy spells in winter. Chicago saw more rain than Seattle during winter.

articles.title: West Michigan birders excited for migration season
articles.summary: Spencer High is a member of the Grand Rapids Audubon Club. According to High, over 471 million birds will fly south across the U.S. Thursday night. The fall migration is one of the most fun times of the year for bird watching.

articles.title: Millions of birds expected to migrate south for winter overnight
articles.summary: Millions of birds are expected to migrate south for winter overnight. Micah Cho talked to a birding expert about what the community can do to help the birds on their journey.    "13 ON YOUR SIDE" is on newsstands now.

articles.title: Wildfire spotted in Peachland
articles.author: Tracey Barnes
articles.summary: A new wildfire has sparked in Peachland. The fire is .0009 hectares in size and considered out of control. The cause of the fire is under investigation. BC Wildfire is aware of the blaze and is responding to it. More information will come.

articles.title: Helene cleanup puts 'a different kind of beauty' on display at Green River
articles.author: Eric Miller
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene destroyed a dozen homes along the Green River in western North Carolina. The town of Saluda, gateway to the river, lost 20% of its tourist revenue due to the damage caused by the storm. Gov. Josh Stein has allocated $9 million for promoting tourism in Western North Carolina, which is a vital part of the economy.

articles.title: Penny Wong rejects Donald Trump's claim that climate change is a ‘con job'
articles.summary: Penny Wong is rebutting Donald Trump's claim that climate change is a 'con job'. She believes some Pacific nations are already experiencing the impacts of global warming. Penny Wong welcomes the news of a meeting between Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump, scheduled for October 20.

articles.title: Climate and the A.I. Revolution
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Chief sustainability officers at Google and Microsoft discuss their companies' net-zero ambitions at the Climate Forward live event. They discuss the rise of artificial intelligence and its potential to increase greenhouse gas emissions in the future. The event is streamed live on Climate Forward's YouTube channel.

articles.title: Sudden 30C temperature rise over Antarctica upends Australia's spring outlook
articles.author: Tom Saunders
articles.summary: Sudden Stratospheric Warming (SSW) is disrupting weather patterns in Australia. SSWs are extremely rare in the Southern Hemisphere, with only two major events documented in the past 60 years. In 2019, the SSW coincided with a record drought, a positive Indian Ocean Dipole and a weak La Niña in the Pacific. In 2025, severe drought is restricted to parts of SA, Victoria and Tasmania, and competing wet influences are present.

articles.title: Dominican Republic issues Yellow Alert for 10 provinces
articles.author: Merit Designs Consulting Group
articles.summary: 10 provinces are now under yellow alert and 8 under green alert due to the risk of river and stream overflows, flash flooding, and landslides from a tropical wave with high cyclonic potential. Operators of small and medium-sized vessels were urged to exercise caution along the Atlantic coast from Cabo Engaño to Cabo Francés Viejo.

articles.title: Will NZ's Net Zero 2050 Climate Targets Include Shipping And Aviation Emissions?
articles.author: Gibbston Valley Wines
articles.summary: Aviation and shipping made up about 9 percent of New Zealand's net domestic emissions. They were excluded from the country's net zero commitment by 2050 under the Paris Accord agreement. Shipping and aviation emissions were included in the government's annual Greenhouse Gas Inventory. The Climate Change Commission carried out its first emissions target review in November. It recommended that transport-related emissions should be included in climate change targets. The minister is expected to decide by November.

articles.title: Why hotter summers are bad for the UK economy
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Even in advanced economies such as the UK, hotter summers are being shown to carry a heavy price due to climate change. The past few summers in the UK have been hotter than in the past few decades in the last few decades.    .

articles.title: Winston Peters drops 'a truth bomb' at UN function on big four emitters
articles.author: Anneke Smith
articles.summary: Foreign Affairs Minister says the world needs to face the 'elephant in the room' on global emissions, during a climate change crisis. Anneke Smith is RNZ's Foreign Affairs Minister. She is also the editor-in-chief of RNZ.

articles.title: Golf Courses Adjust to a Changing Climate
articles.author: Michael Croley
articles.summary: The global climate is changing and golf courses are trying to adapt. Many clubs are facing water shortages, while some in coastal areas have to deal with extreme weather events that wash away dunes or even leave holes underwater. Golf courses in temperate and cool regions are seeing longer, warmer golf seasons.

articles.title: ‘Greenland 2: Migration' Trailer Sends Gerard Butler to the Ends of the Earth
articles.author: The Wrap
articles.summary: 'Greenland 2: Migration' is coming out early next year. It's the sequel to the 2020 disaster film 'Greenland'. It starred Gerard Butler as a man trying to hide his family in a secret bunker while a comet is heading towards Earth. The first trailer has been released.

articles.title: Conspiracy theorists, you were right: The climate change agenda is the depopulation agenda, even though no one knows what the global population is
articles.author: Rhoda
articles.summary: On Tuesday, The Guardian published an article that admits the climate agenda is the depopulation agenda. The article boldly claims the global human population is increasing by 200,000 people a day. The world's population is a guesstimate, so how can they know it's increasing by that number? The article was written by a journalist who won an award for his 'agenda-setting journalism on the climate crisis'

articles.title: Hot air: on U.S. President Donald Trump's rant against climate change science
articles.summary: Donald Trump delivered an address to the UNGA that was allergic to facts. He said Europe's decades-long trimming of its carbon footprint had come at the expense of factories and job losses. To him, the increasing adoption of solar and wind energy was evidence of countries being on the 'brink of destruction' because of pursuing a green agenda.

articles.title: Maharashtra's Farmers Battle Nature: Nine Years of Weather Woes and Crop Losses
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Maharashtra has been hit by adverse weather events for the past nine years. More than 605.26 lakh hectares have suffered due to excessive rains, hailstorms, and droughts. The state has had to pay out over Rs 54,600 crore in compensation to the affected farmers.

articles.title: Malta among EU States hardest hit by extreme weather, study finds
articles.author: Agenzia di Stampa Italpress
articles.summary: Malta's economy is among the most exposed in the European Union to extreme weather events. Heatwaves, droughts and floods will slash EU-wide economic activity by €43 billion in 2025. By 2029, the long-term damage could rise to €126 billion compared with a scenario without extreme weather.

articles.title: Aliyev warns of Caspian Sea ecological crisis at UNGA
articles.summary: Ilham Aliyev raised the issue of the Caspian Sea's ecological state in 2022. Today, the situation is even worse. The main reason is not climate change. Joint efforts of the coastal states are needed to prevent an ecological disaster. Azerbaijan is ready to cooperate with the UN in solving this problem.

articles.title: Climate disruptions threatening women's health: study
articles.author: Staff Correspondent
articles.summary: Experts have proposed three climate-resilient intervention packages for women's sexual and reproductive health and rights (SRHR) in Bangladesh. They focus on community-based, facility-based and shelter-based approaches. They were presented yesterday at a programme titled "Dissemination on Impact of Climate Change on Women's and Girls' SRHR: Developing Critical Evidence and Designing Intervention Strategy and Package to Overcome Challenges in Bangladesh".

articles.title: Grizzled Gerard Butler Faces a World-Ending Disaster in First ‘Greenland: Migration' Trailer
articles.author: Collider
articles.summary: Gerard Butler starred in Greenland. Greenland: Migration is coming to theaters early. STX Films has debuted the first trailer for the film's official sequel, which is coming out five years after the original film.       "Greenland: Migration" is out now.

articles.title: Ghana's mangroves under threats – Hɛn Mpoano calls for urgent national rescue
articles.summary: Ghanaian NGO, 'Hɛn Mpoano', has warned that the country's mangrove forests are disappearing due to human activities. The NGO has launched a restoration drive under the African Forest Landscape Restoration Initiative, aiming to plant 200,000 seedlings in the Amanzule wetlands by 2030.

articles.title: Expert explains how warmer weather is impacting Chicago-area fall foliage
articles.summary: It's the first week of fall and we're starting to see a few fall colors. Some trees in the Chicago area have started experiencing early fall colors or brown leaves due to warmer-than-normal weather conditions and other factors. The Morton Arboretum grounds are open daily from 9:00 a.m. to sunset.

articles.title: Who's the Scammer?
articles.author: Postmedia Staff
articles.summary: Donald Trump said in the UN General Assembly that climate change is a hoax. He also said that the conclusions of the entire scientific community are 'predictions made by stupid people'. Many people will believe anything they hear or read. For centuries people believed that the earth was flat, because it looked flat, and there are still 'flat earth' proponents to this day. The tobacco industry tried to hide the scientific proof that smoking is a major cause of lung cancer, and the same suspicion can be directed towards the oil industry.

articles.title: Fullerton Ocean Park Hotel's lack of defences exposes climate vulnerability in wake of Super Typhoon Ragasa
articles.author: Dimsumdaily Hong Kong
articles.summary: The Fullerton Ocean Park Hotel in Wong Chuk Hang has resumed operations despite major damage to its waterfront facilities following Super Typhoon Ragasa. The hotel's ground floor lobby remains barricaded with white wooden boards after its glass doors were shattered by waves measuring six to eight metres high. The property opened in 2022 after major typhoons like Mangkhut in 2018 and is positioned outside the protective range of the Aberdeen Typhoon Shelter breakwater. The surrounding area presents a scene of extensive damage, with palm trees uprooted, the hotel's signage toppled and an escalator structure severely twisted and broken.

articles.title: China has announced its first target to cut emissions in real terms. What does it ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: China accounts for nearly a third of the world's total emissions, so any cuts it makes will make a substantial difference for the world and for fossil fuel exports. Sign up for climate and environment editor Adam Morton's free Clear to get the latest news on the Clear platform.

articles.title: St. Michaels Commissioners discuss sea level rise projects
articles.author: Ahmad Garnett
articles.summary: Roy Meyer of the Climate Change Sea Level Rise Commission and engineers presented key sea-level rise mitigation projects to the St. Michaels commissioners on Wednesday. The commissioners will discuss the projects with the commissioners on Thursday. The meeting will take place at the commissioners' request.

articles.title: Community presses Hawaii's new Green Fee Advisory Council
articles.author: Dan Nakaso
articles.summary: Hawaii's Transient Accommodations Tax will increase by 0.75 percentage point on January 1st. The new Green Fee Advisory Council will make recommendations on how the money should be spent to combat climate change. The council's chair, Jeff Mikulina, said it's a first in the nation.

articles.title: State Awards $196k To Herring Pond Tribe For Climate Resilience And Rematriation Efforts
articles.author: Bourne Briefs
articles.summary: The Herring Pond Wampanoag Tribe has received a $196,230 climate resilience grant for the Tidmarsh Farms Planning and Acquisition Project in Plymouth. The grant is from the Healey-Driscoll Administration's Municipal Vulnerability Preparedness (MVP) program.

articles.title: Barnett: Food Security Must Be a Caribbean Priority.
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: The 19th Caribbean Week of Agriculture will be held in St. Kitts and Nevis from 29 September to 3 October 2025. The event is themed 'Sowing Change, Harvesting Resilience: Transforming Our Caribbean Food Systems for 2025 and Beyond'. It is aimed at reducing the Region's food import bill by 25 percent within the next five years.

articles.title: African civil society denounces Trump's ‘climate hoax' remarks as dangerous and irresponsible
articles.summary: Donald Trump called climate change a hoax at the UN General Assembly. PACJA, the umbrella body of African CSOs on climate change, says such statements are scientifically false and morally indefensible. The group calls on all responsible leaders to reject climate denialism in every form.

articles.title: TALAT: WHAT IN THE WORLD IS A "GRUE JAY?!?"
articles.summary: Experts say a strange bird found in Texas could be the product of climate change. Today in TALAT, we talk about the strange bird and climate change in general. Today on Talat is at 10:30 a.m. ET with John Sutter.

articles.title: ‘Hidden costs' of climate emergency are worsening California's affordability crisis
articles.author: Dani Anguiano
articles.summary: The average American born in 2024 will likely face up to $500,000 in additional lifetime costs from climate crisis in California. Those who experience more severe effects will see more than $1m in costs. California has long been one of the most expensive states in the nation with its high cost of living and expensive housing. Since the rollback of pandemic era policies, California has developed the highest poverty rate in the US. The state has also had to grapple with increasingly extreme weather fueled by climate change from devastating and deadly wildfires.

articles.title: China has announced its first target to cut emissions in real terms. What does it mean for Australia?
articles.author: Graham Readfearn
articles.summary: On Thursday, China's president, Xi Jinping, announced a new target to cut its greenhouse gas emissions by 7% to 10% by 2035. China's emissions are about 29% of the global total, more than twice that of the United States, the world's second biggest emitter. Australia's first national climate risk assessment laid out the toll on the economy, on communities and on habitats and wildlife.

articles.title: Asheville's climate plan offers guide to Helene recovery and rebuilding, but much work remains
articles.author: Bpr News
articles.summary: A year after Tropical Storm Helene, Asheville's recovery is focused on climate resilience. A 124-page climate document recommended actions in key areas, from forest protection and community outreach to fixing roads and bridges to withstand floods. Some steps have been taken, notably a $40 million dam improvement project at the North Fork Reservoir and improvements to weather alert systems, but most of the recommendations remain untouched.

articles.title: Millions of Birds Fly 'Highways' Across the U.S. – and Their Migration Routes Are Breaking Down
articles.summary: Climate change is disrupting bird migration. Binghamton University researchers are studying how migratory birds are responding to environmental changes over time. They are without proper habitats, food and putting them at risk of extreme weather, according to the researchers.   .

articles.title: Crime in Australia's Victoria up 18.3 pct to record-high
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: The number of criminal incidents reported in the southeast Australian state of Victoria rose by over 18 percent to a record high in 2024-25, according to official figures released on Thursday. The data was released by the Australian Ministry of Home Affairs on Thursday and is based on official data.

articles.title: Albertans concerned about extreme heat, but some don't believe in climate change: poll
articles.author: Michael Franklin
articles.summary: Albertans are most concerned about extreme weather events and climate change. Many Albertans are forced to stay indoors due to poor air quality and emotional stress. Some Albertans don't believe in climate change, according to Leger's poll. The poll was conducted online on a sample size of 1,521 Canadians 18 years of age or older between Sept. 15 and 21.

articles.title: IMD forecasts rain in south Bengal for 7 days, Durga Puja festival likely to be wet
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: IMD has predicted light to moderate rainfall in southern West Bengal for the next seven days due to a low-pressure system over the Bay of Bengal. Heavy rain is expected in South 24 Parganas and Jhargram. Fishermen are advised against venturing into the sea.

articles.title: Australian renters should champion lower immigration
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: There were 1,227,000 net migrants in Australia over the 33 months to Q1 2025. As a result, advertised rents have skyrocketed for Australian renters. Justin Fabo from shows how this has affected the rental market in his blog post.

articles.title: Researchers in Australia combine eDNA, visual surveys to track fish migrations
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Researchers in Australia have developed a new method combining environmental DNA (eDNA) and visual surveys to track tropical fish species migrating into cooler waters as oceans warm due to climate change. They surveyed fish communities along 2,000 km of Australia's east coast. More than 12,000 species have already shifted their homes across land, freshwater and the sea.

articles.title: Hurricane Helene 1 year anniversary events
articles.author: Kenneth Reece
articles.summary: On Saturday, September 27, 2025, communities across the High Country will gather to mark one year since Hurricane Helene. David LaMotte's keynote and his evening concert will be held in the Appalachian Theatre. The Town of Banner Elk invites the community to come together from 2 to 4 p.m. for 'Banner Elk Remembers'. The gathering will take place on the lawn of the Historic Banner Elk School.

articles.title: Australia's New Climate Report Falsely Ties $40 Billion A Year In Disaster Costs To Climate Change
articles.author: Roger Pielke Jr.
articles.summary: The National Climate Risk Assessment (NCRA) said that climate change could cost Australians $40 billion per year by 2050. Colvin Review says that the forecast total economic cost of natural disasters across Australia in 2023-24 is $11.8 billion and is predicted to increase to $40.3 billion in 2049-50. Andy Pitman, a climate scientist at the University of New South Wales, explains that the future of extreme events in Australia is uncertain.

articles.title: Jammu & Kashmir's Homeless to Receive Land After Devastating Floods
articles.author: Jammu
articles.summary: Jammu and Kashmir Chief Minister Omar Abdullah promised five marlas of land to every family left homeless by the natural disaster. The announcement was made during his interaction with residents of Duggain village in Billawar tehsil, Kathua district. Abdullah conducted an aerial survey to assess the scale of damage in the flood-affected areas.

articles.title: Extreme wildfire warning issued for Scottish Borders by SFRS
articles.author: Lucette Wood
articles.summary: Serge Kabamba, SFRS group commander, has issued a wildfire warning for Wednesday (September 24) and today (September 25). It is the first wildfire warning in September since 2000 and the 13th warning since year. He urges the public to exercise extreme caution and think twice before using anything involving a naked flame.

articles.title: New Report Finds Seven Of Nine Key Earth Systems Are At Risk
articles.author: BERNAMA
articles.summary: The majority of Earth's vital functions are at risk, according to a new report by the Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research. Seven out of nine critical stress limits have been exceeded, with ocean acidification emerging as a new concern. Two of the identified stress limits are still within safe limits.

articles.title: Global Warming Surge: Understanding the Impact of a 10-Degree Temperature Increase
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: A 10°C rise in global average temperature represents a catastrophic scenario with implications far beyond simply warmer weather. The current climate models predict warming will stay below this level this century with aggressive mitigation. The consequences for human societies are dire, including food security, health, and migration.

articles.title: EarthTalk: Joe Rogan Is Dead Wrong on Global Warming
articles.author: Mitch Maley
articles.summary: Joe Rogan is a comedian and a podcaster on 'The Joe Rogan Experience.' He claims that climate change is exaggerated and that the planet is cooling. However, scientific evidence warns that the Earth is warming unusually fast due to human activity. Since the industrial revolution, temperatures have been climbing at a speed that rivals any other point in history.

articles.title: Record-breaking glacier melt on Svalbard
articles.author: Henry Patton
articles.summary: The summer of 2024 was the worst melting season in Svalbard's history. In just a few months, the island lost about 1% of all its ice. This amount is almost the same as what Greenland lost during the same time period. The glacier melt accounted for 10% of the sea-level rise contribution from all glaciers in the world. Most of the 2024 glacier melt occurred during a 6-week period of persistent atmospheric circulation pattern.

articles.title: Proposed federal cuts could threaten Great Lakes, Michigan economy
articles.author: Wxpr
articles.summary: Proposed federal cuts to NOAA and EPA could affect Michigan's economy, public health, and Great Lakes protections. Leaders gathered this week along the Rogue River to urge Congress to reject the proposals. The agencies provide reliable scientific information that allows collaboration between farmers, industry, and communities.

articles.title: Coalition Demand Urgent Action After Trump's Dismissal Of Climate Change At UNGA
articles.author: Kashmir Observer
articles.summary: Donald Trump dismissed climate change as 'the greatest con job'. A coalition of countries pushing for stronger climate action on Wednesday said that the urgency of international action is growing as we approach the 1.5 degrees Celsius threshold and tipping points threaten to throw the planet into an irreversible catastrophe.

articles.title: Unusually cold winter ahead for Delhi-NCR? How La Niña could bring North India's coldest season in years, all you need to know
articles.author: Vanshika Tyagi
articles.summary: Delhi, Gurgaon, Noida, Ghaziabad, and Faridabad's winters are expected to be the harshest this year due to La Niña. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a 'La Niña Watch' warning. January 2026 could be the coldest months in recent history.

articles.title: African Leaders Commit to Climate-Health Nexus and Adaptation Solutions
articles.author: Friday Phiri
articles.summary: The Second Africa Climate Summit (ACS2) was held in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, from 8-10 September. African leaders committed to advancing climate-resilient and adaptive health systems on the continent. The summit brought together African leaders, policymakers, youth, civil society, development partners, and private sector.

articles.title: Why the UK's favourite dish is under threat
articles.author: Bryony Gooch
articles.summary: Scientists have warned that North Sea cod is in "grave danger of collapse" in most British waters. Fishermen should avoid catching cod in English Channel, North Sea up to Norway and west of Scotland, and extend previous warnings for the Irish and Celtic seas. The only exception for sustainable fishing is around the island of Rockall, where a mere 11 tonnes of cod can be caught.

articles.title: ‘Empty seats': Albanese's UN address shows world's ‘not paying attention' to Australia
articles.summary: Paul Murray will discuss Anthony Albanese's climate action at the UN and China's pledge to reduce emissions on tonight's episode of Paul Murray Live on Sky News host Paul Murray. Paul Murray will also discuss migration, migration and more on the show tonight.

articles.title: Minister Kimmins gets an insight into the science behind flood risk management (Northern Ireland Executive)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Infrastructure Minister Liz Kimmins visited Rivers Headquarters at Loughry today to get an insight into the science behind flood risk management. September is "Preparedness Month" in Australia and there is an increase in flooding and flood risk due to changing weather patterns.

articles.title: Why storms are hitting the East Sea so often this year
articles.author: Vn Express
articles.summary: There have been nine typhoons and four tropical depressions in the South China Sea, Vietnam's East Sea, in the first nine months of 2025. Since June, the region has seen storm after storm sweep in. September alone recorded four typhoons, two more than the average for this month. In the past five years, September has rarely seen more than six storms, making 2025 an outlier. People are advised to prepare evacuation plans, food, clean water and backup power in case of prolonged disruptions.

articles.title: Dr Mpango insists on the Loss and Damage Fund to address impacts of climate change in Africa
articles.author: Aveline Kitomary
articles.summary: Dr Philip Mpango insists on the timely provision of the Loss and Damage Fund as a key financial mechanism to assist developing countries to tackle the adverse effects of climate change. The fund was formally launched at the 27th United Nations Conference on Climate Change (COP27) in Egypt in 2022.

articles.title: Florida Climate Week™ Brings Over 75 Events to Communities Statewide
articles.author: Vo Lo Foundation
articles.summary: Florida Climate Week returns for its fifth year. It unites communities across the state with more than 75 in-person and virtual events focused on building resilience and advancing local climate solutions. It's aimed at strengthening climate resilience at a time of challenges in Florida.

articles.title: Canada: order to cull more than 400 ostriches over bird flu fears ruffles feathers
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: 69 ostrichs died of flu-like illness at a Canadian ostrich farm. Animal rights activists and prominent Trump supporters protested at the farm even though 69 birds died. Police warn that the protest is fanned by the growing furore around the farm.

articles.title: Philippines cancels classes, flights as storm Bualoi makes landfall
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Bualoi is forecast to intensify into a typhoon on September 26 and then hit the southern end of the Philippines' largest island, Luzon. The weather service warned of widespread flooding and landslides in mountainous areas and waves of up to three metres could pose a serious threat to lives. Around 1,500 people are stranded in ports of Bicol. Super Typhoon Ragasa killed nine people in the Philippines.

articles.title: Gaza aid flotilla 'undeterred' by Israel's assault
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg talks about the recent assault on the Gaza flotilla and the activists' determination to break Israel's illegal siege. Read more Al Jazeera – Breaking News, World News and Video from Al Jazeera here.   .

articles.title: Climate migration set to rise sharply by 2050 as climate stress intensifies, says report
articles.author: AGATHA NGOTHO
articles.summary: By 2050, up to 5% of Africa's population could be forced to migrate due to climate stress. Global data from the Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC) revealed that disasters triggered nearly 265 million displacements between 2015 and 2024, with 90% linked to floods and storms.

articles.title: No more tax cuts: Western North Carolinians deserve a budget that prioritizes people
articles.author: Alex Campbell
articles.summary: It's been a year since Hurricane Helene hit Western North Carolina. The combined funding for recovery from federal, state, and private sources is only $15 billion. Governor Stein has renewed the request for $13.5 billion in federal funding for Helene recovery on Sept. 15, 2025. This money could be used to address the many outstanding needs in Western NC.

articles.title: Climate activists condemn Trump's UN climate denial remarks
articles.author: Lilys Njeru
articles.summary: US President Donald Trump dismissed climate change as a hoax at the UN General Assembly. Pan-African Climate Justice Alliance (PACJA) and World Resources Institute (WRI) condemned his remarks. President Ruto stressed the urgency of addressing the climate crisis and advancing climate action.

articles.title: EarthTalk: Global warming's strain on your eyes
articles.summary: Pauline Mercy asks EarthTalk about the link between climate change and eye problems for humans. Rising global temperatures, worsening air quality, shifting disease patterns and increasing water scarcity are all contributing factors that heighten the risk of eye-related problems worldwide. Wearing sunglasses that block ultraviolet rays and reducing exposure to polluted air can lessen irritation and disease risk.

articles.title: Philippines cancels flights as new storm looms
articles.summary: Severe Tropical Storm Bualoi is forecast to intensify into a typhoon on Friday and then hit the southern end of the Philippines' largest island, Luzon. The Philippines is hit by an average of 20 storms and typhoons each year. Super Typhoon Ragasa passed over the country's far northern end and killed at least nine people.

articles.title: UK could see fish and chips shortages as cod supply in ‘grave danger'
articles.author: The Independent
articles.summary: Scientists warn that North Sea cod is in danger of collapse and are concerned about the health of cod in the North Sea. The cod are in a 'grave danger' of collapse, according to the scientists' findings. The study was published in the journal "Current Biology".

articles.title: Cork communities march to ‘protect' prime farmland from solar projects
articles.author: Kevin Galvin
articles.summary: East Cork Communities Unite will march from the Midleton Distillery to the Courthouse this Saturday at noon to protest against industrial-scale solar farm developments in the local area. They say they risk the loss of fertile farmland, pose a direct threat to food security and impact local wildlife and livelihoods.

articles.title: Over 60,000 Europeans died from heat during 2024 summer: Study - Health - Life & Style
articles.summary: More than 60,000 people died from heat in Europe during last year's record-breaking summer, according to a benchmark study. Europe is heating up twice as fast as the global average. Italy was the country with the most heat deaths last summer with an estimated 19,000. Greece had the highest rate with 574 deaths per million people, followed by Bulgaria and Serbia.

articles.title: Bipartisan approach needed on energy supply
articles.author: Cathy Wilcox
articles.summary: Both Labor and the Coalition agree Australia is running out of time to replace the energy deficit due to most coal-fired plants reaching their end of life by about 2035. Australia's contribution to greenhouse gas emissions is through its export of fossil fuels. Donald Trump told the UN that climate change is “greatest con job’.

articles.title: Experts forecast one of the coldest winters this year in Pakistan
articles.author: Our Correspondent
articles.summary: La Niña is known for disrupting air circulation and jet stream patterns, often resulting in significantly colder winters, extended frost periods and more intense snowfall in many parts of the world. US Climate Prediction Center has issued alerts based on oceanic temperature shifts, which are expected to trigger La Niña conditions in the coming months.

articles.title: Two climate scientists on how to use emotion in the climate crisis
articles.author: New Scientist
articles.summary: Kate Marvel and Tim Lenton explain how to tackle the tricky feelings aroused by climate change and harness them to take action on climate change in their book "Climate Change: From Anger to Hope" (Simon & Schuster, £12.99, p.99).

articles.title: Civic Assembly Launches Initiative for an Ideal Climate in Pescara City
articles.author: Dr. Priya Deshmukh
articles.summary: Civic Assembly launches Pescara Climate Resilience Project to address climate change in the Adriatic city of Abruzzo, Italy. The project focuses on climate change mitigation and adaptation strategies. It includes urban greening, reforestation, green infrastructure, renewable energy, water conservation, and coastal protection measures. It also focuses on citizen participation in the project.

articles.title: Southern Africa: SADC Strengthens Technical Capacity for Agrometeorological Services
articles.summary: The Southern African Development Community (SADC) Secretariat convened a regional workshop in Johannesburg, South Africa, from 17 to 25 September 2025, to build technical capacity in the use of the ClimSA Station platform for agrometeorological services. The SADC region remains highly vulnerable to climate extremes, from recurrent droughts and crop failures to floods.

articles.title: Beginning Of End For Destructive Fossil Fuels
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Columbia and Vanuatu will host the First International Conference for the Phase-Out of Fossil Fuels in April, 2026. The Australia Institute has been working to phase out fossil fuels for decades. Australia is the world's second largest fossil fuel exporter and fifth largest producer.

articles.title: One year since Helene: More than 100 killed in NC, communities still rebuilding
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: One year after Hurricane Helene ravaged western North Carolina, the extent of the damage is becoming clearer. More than 100 people were killed in the state. Communities are still rebuilding.      Â   .   "Hurricane Helene" was a Category 4 hurricane.

articles.title: Wet days ahead as IMD warns of heavy rain and gusty winds from Panchami
articles.author: Our Web Desk
articles.summary: There is a low-pressure system forming over the Bay of Bengal, which is likely to intensify into a depression by September 26 and cross the Odisha-Andhra coast the next morning. South Bengal, including Kolkata, will receive light to moderate rain almost every day for the next week. The IMD has issued an alert for September 27, warning of heavy rainfall at isolated places in South 24 Parganas and Jhargram.

articles.title: Countries clamour for urgent action after Trump calls climate change a ‘con job'
articles.author: Nh Digital
articles.summary: The past eight years are the warmest on record, with global greenhouse gas emissions still rising. The IPCC's 2023 Synthesis Report warns that the world is surpassing adaptation limits, with losses from extreme events rising yearly and plateauing at points where 'no amount of adaptation will suffice'. Antonio Guterres, UN secretary-general, convened a Climate Summit during the UNGA.

articles.title: One year later, Slater-Marietta rallies and calls for better resources after Helene
articles.author: Terry Benjamin II
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene devastated the Slater-Marietta community in Greenville County, South Carolina on Sept. 27, 2024. The community was cut off by rising floodwaters, toppled trees and without power. Neighbors helped each other, shared food and shelter.

articles.title: One year later, Slater-Marietta rallies and calls for better resources after Helene
articles.author: Terry Benjamin II
articles.summary: Tropical Storm Helene devastated the Slater-Marietta community in Greenville County, South Carolina on Sept. 27, cutting it off from the rest of the community. The community has a population of 4,936 people, 22.1 percent of whom live below the poverty line. The average poverty rate in the county is around 13 percent.

articles.title: 'Everyone is on edge and anxious': Ardoyne man Fra witnesses drone attack on Gaza flotilla
articles.author: Conor Mcparland
articles.summary: Fra Hughes from Ardoyne is one of 350 pro-Palestinian activists taking part in the Global Sumud Flotilla. On Tuesday night, flotilla boats were targeted in a major drone attack which has been blamed on Israel. Fra is the volunteer director of the Palestine Aid charity, which has raised £115,000 in aid for Gaza over the last year. Israel blocked two earlier attempts by activists to reach Gaza by sea in June and July.

articles.title: Council seeks feedback on 10-year plan to tackle coastal erosion
articles.author: Kendra Jewell
articles.summary: Coastal erosion is an ongoing issue for residents at Old Bar. MidCoast Council is asking the community for feedback to help guide a 10-year coastal management plan to protect the beaches in the area. The council is also looking for volunteers to help with the design of the plan.

articles.title: Energy Asia 2025 opening addresses set tone for discussions on tailored transition strategies
articles.author: Morning Studio Editors
articles.summary: The global energy transition is an urgent necessity. Global clean energy spending hit about US$1.8 trillion in 2023. It will need to nearly double to US$4.5 trillion each year by the early 2030s to align with the net-zero goal. About three-quarters of all greenhouse gas emissions still stem from the energy sector.

articles.title: Fall feeling a little drab? Mother nature may be missing her environmental cue
articles.author: Anya Zoledziowski
articles.summary: Some clients have asked Jessilynn Wong to move their autumn photoshoots to the first half of October to capture the autumn foliage. Hot and dry conditions have stressed trees out in different ways across Canada this year, disrupting all sorts of processes, including colour transformation.

articles.title: China unveils first emissions cut plan, calls out U.S. climate denial
articles.summary: China announced its first-ever plan to cut greenhouse gas emissions by 7-10% from peak levels by 2035. President Xi Jinping also pledged to expand wind and solar capacity sixfold from 2020 levels and increase the share of non-fossil fuels in China's energy mix to over 30%.

articles.title: Pakistan's agricultural sector and food security hit hard by flooding
articles.author: Mumbai Office
articles.summary: Pakistan is facing the most severe flooding in over four decades in parts of Punjab, its agricultural heartland. Since late June, relentless monsoon rains and water releases from upstream dams in India have combined to inundate vast tracts of eastern Pakistan. Punjab has borne the brunt, with 2.9 million people evacuated and entire riverine communities displaced. The timing of the floods has been particularly damaging for Kharif crops. Around 220,000 hectares of rice submerged between August 1 and September 16, mainly in Punjab's Sialkot and Narowal districts.

articles.title: African Climate Alliance Condemns Trump's UN Climate Denial
articles.author: Business
articles.summary: President Donald Trump dismissed global warming as a hoax during his UN General Assembly address on Tuesday. Pan-African Climate Justice Alliance (PACJA) issued a scathing response, calling Trump's statements scientifically false and morally indefensible. PACJA is one of Africa's largest climate advocacy networks, coordinating efforts across multiple countries. Recent months have witnessed severe droughts across the Horn of Africa, devastating cyclones in Mozambique, and unprecedented flooding displacing West African communities. Climate change is a daily struggle for millions across Africa.

articles.title: Canada's Future in Hydro-Meteorological Services
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: The Meteorological Service of Canada (MSC) is responsible for providing accurate and timely forecasts for everyone in Canada. Public hydro-meteorological services are operating at a transformative time, the public is accessing information in new ways, the impacts of climate change are being felt across the country, and AI has the potential to radically change how services are delivered. Canada's weather service is subject to changing geopolitical structures and financial constraints. MSC asked CCA to convene an expert panel to examine the essential functions of a public hydro meteorological service.

articles.title: From Trump's 'Con Job' Claim to EU Rift, COP30 Won't Be Easy in a Tipping World
articles.author: Anoushka Rajesh
articles.summary: Donald Trump's climate change speech at the UN General Assembly has thrown a spanner in the works for COP30. The Quint explains how the US, China, the Global South, and the EU are doing their part in making COP30 a success. The COP30 is taking place in Belém, Brazil in less than two months.

articles.title: Nations deliver new climate targets ahead of climate summit
articles.author: Deutsche Welle
articles.summary: There are less than two months to go before the start of the international COP 30 climate summit in Belem, Brazil. The deadline for the 2035 NDC was in February, but few of the 195 parties that have ratified the Paris Agreement have met the date. China's pledge to cut emissions by 7-10% from peak is both "underwhelming and transformative" according to 350.org. The EU issued a statement of intent to put forward a climate target before the November conference with a 2035 greenhouse gas reduction ranging between 66.25% and 72.5%.

articles.title: Tanzania, UNCDF launch climate risk, vulnerability assessment for LGAs
articles.author: Dailynews Reporter
articles.summary: Tanzania has launched its first-ever Climate Risk and Vulnerability Assessment for Local Government Authorities (LGAs) in Mainland Tanzania and Zanzibar. The report provides science-based mapping of climate threats at the local level. It is designed to equip policymakers, planners and communities with actionable data for location-specific solutions.

articles.title: Afternoon Update: PM urges UN to unite; Bali hospital denies alleged organ theft; and recipes for the footy final
articles.author: Mike Hohnen
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese has pushed back on isolationism and criticised Donald Trump's rejection of climate science at the UN. The PM also resurrected a bid for Australia to win a temporary seat on the UN security council in 2029-30. Tens of thousands of people attended Xi Jinping's military parade marking 80 years since the defeat of Japan in the second world war.

articles.title: Heavy Rainfall Likely To Lash Odisha Today As Low-Pressure System Develops
articles.author: Ommcom News
articles.summary: A low-pressure system is all set to form over the central Bay of Bengal. It will intensify into a depression by September 26 and cross southern Odisha and northern Andhra Pradesh by September 27. The weather system will bring heavy rainfall to the state. Several districts in Odisha have been placed under warning due to the impending weather system.

articles.title: Manual for climate change adaptation underway, says NEWMAP
articles.author: Latestnigeriannews
articles.summary: Nigeria Erosion and Watershed Management Project (NEWMAP) has developed a guidance manual for climate change agenda in the country. The manual is intended to reduce long-term climate-related challenges in Nigeria. NEWMAP is also developing a guidebook for adaptation to climate change.

articles.title: Indigenous Key to 2035 Climate Goals, Fair Transition Needed
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Indigenous people and their land will play a crucial part if Australia wants to meet its 2035 climate targets. Energy justice and sovereignty need to be central in Australia's climate policy. Indigenous Australians struggle to consume the energy they need, and they are more exposed to the worst impacts of climate change. Canada has a range of renewable energy and efficiency programs aimed at reducing dependence on diesel.

articles.title: Grave warning for Australia after Trump's explosive speech: 'Your country is going to fail'
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Donald Trump's scepticism about climate change is impacting Australia's aspirations to reduce emissions. Dr Bill Hare is a senior scientist and CEO of the Climate Analytics thinktank. Australia has faced more severe and frequent extreme weather events due to global warming. The Paris Agreement, adopted by 195 Parties at the UN Climate Change Conference in 2015, agreed to limit the world's average temperature rise this century to well below 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels, while pursuing a limit of 1.5 degrees.

articles.title: Sinking islands, vanishing forests: World leaders call for urgent climate action (UNOG
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: Leaders came to the United Nations General Assembly on Wednesday with a common message: climate change is no longer a problem.    - from the rainforests of Central America to low-lying atolls in the Pacific and drought-stricken plains in Africa.

articles.title: Daylight saving time starts in New Zealand this Sunday: Everything you need to know
articles.author: Natasha Gordon
articles.summary: Clocks across Aotearoa will spring forward by an hour this Sunday at 2am as daylight saving time begins. It will be darker when you wake up in the morning, but the sun will set an hour later.      Â

articles.title: Climate causing heat deaths in Britain
articles.summary: At least 1,147 people died in the UK this summer due to extreme heatwaves caused by climate change-driven heatwaves. The UK saw its hottest summer on record this year. The heat was responsible for 68 per cent of the 24,400 total heat deaths in 854 European cities or areas over the three months.

articles.title: Farmers' bird count highlights value of agri-environment schemes
articles.author: John Sleigh
articles.summary: The Science for Sustainable Agriculture (SSA) group wants Defra to review its use of a 'limited and highly selective' indicator list of 19 species. SSA argues that the current list excludes common species such as carrion crow and chaffinch, recent farmland arrivals like the herring gull, and successful raptors including the red kite and buzzard. According to SSA, the UK's total songbird population has actually risen slightly – from 70.3 million in 1997 to 71.3million in 2024, an increase of 1.5%.

articles.title: ‘Marginal farmers, fishers remain ignored in UN's COP'
articles.author: Anniversary Issue-I
articles.summary: Md Shamsuddoha, Chief Executive of the Center for Participatory Research and Development, said the concerns of small farmers and fishers have long been ignored at COP negotiations, even though they are on the frontline of climate change impacts. Gawher Nayeem Wahra argued that mismanagement of rivers, not just climate change, was driving the water crisis.

articles.title: Unseasonal rain destroyed 519 lakh ha of farmland across Maharashtra in past nine years
articles.author: Sanjeev Shivadekar
articles.summary: In the past nine years, 519 lakh hectares of farmland across Maharashtra have been damaged due to unseasonal rains between 2015 and 2024. Chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis admitted that climate change was a major reason for repeated losses. Even the rain-deficient Marathwada region was now reeling under excess rainfall.

articles.title: Hanging Rock vs. Storm Boy: which iconic Aussie movie location is your next trip?
articles.author: Mal Chenu
articles.summary: Pelican flocks are still soaring across vast skies and waterways along with ducks, swans, cormorants, gulls, terns, grebes, sea eagles and more than 230 migratory bird species. If the movie made you yearn to live rough, head for campsites dotting the dunes and walking trails criss-crossing the traditional lands of the Ngarrindjeri people.

articles.title: AOSIS, LDCs insist on 1.5 degrees goal
articles.summary: The Alliance of Small Island Developing States (AOSIS) and the Least Developed Countries (LDCs) Group are pressing in on their advocacy to affirm 1.5 degrees Celsius as the global temperature goal to restrain catastrophic climate change. They also call for a suite of other actions to bolster their resilience.

articles.title: Climate Change Poses Severe Risks for Low-Income Earners: Insights from ILO Report on Pakistan's Vulnerabilities and Needs for Action
articles.author: Daniel Foster
articles.summary: There is a dramatic escalation in the impact of climate change on the global workforce, with 71% of workers already feeling its effects in 2024. Low-income earners will bear the brunt of its economic consequences, with 75% of income losses. The report estimates that while six million jobs in fossil fuel industries may be lost, approximately 24 million new jobs could be created in renewable energy and related sectors. Pakistan is particularly vulnerable to climate change.

articles.title: Storm Ragasa weakens but Vietnam's Quang Ninh province braces for impact
articles.summary: Storm Ragasa weakened on Thursday morning, but still poses serious risks for northern coastal provinces. Quang Ninh Province mobilised thousands of personnel and equipment to respond. More than 3,000 armed forces officers and soldiers, along with dozens of vehicles, vessels and boats, have been deployed. Over 7,900 aquaculture farms have reinforced cages and more than 5,000 workers were evacuated.

articles.title: High stakes as world nations face pressure ahead of climate summit
articles.author: Francis
articles.summary: The UN stressed that climate disasters are now 'wreaking havoc' on every continent. Under the 2015 Paris Agreement, governments committed to keeping the rise in global temperatures 'well below' 2 degrees Celsius above pre-industrial levels and to pursue efforts to limit warming to 1.5 degrees. Only 47 countries have submitted updated climate goals, representing just 24% of global emissions. Major emitters, including the European Union and India, have yet to finalize their submissions. The European Union, often seen as a climate leader, is struggling to maintain unity. China, the world's largest emitter, is also under scrutiny.

articles.title: Unchecked Climate Change May Slash GDP by 24% by 2100
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Nearly a quarter of the global GDP per capita could be lost by 2100 compared to a "no further warming" baseline. Abiding by the Paris Agreement goals may generate a 0.25% global benefit. Hotter and low-income countries might face economic losses 30-60% higher than global average.

articles.title: Storm Shadows: How Helene impacted Avery County's youth
articles.summary: Hurricane Helene devastated Avery County a year ago. For children and teenagers, the storm disrupted their sense of safety, stability, and even their path to learning. Children whose homes were damaged or destroyed often found themselves living with relatives, in temporary housing, or even in shelters. Schools became emergency shelters or supply distribution centers, delaying the start of classes. Some children experience heightened fear whenever heavy rain falls, associating storms with danger, while others struggle with sleep disruptions, flashbacks, or difficulty concentrating in school.

articles.title: Brisbane crane index shows shift to residential ... for now
articles.author: The Age
articles.summary: Brisbane's crane count shows a 12 per cent increase in the number of cranes punctuating the city's skyline since last year. The latest count was taken from the Brisbane City Council's website. The number has increased by more than 10 per cent.

articles.title: Millions Of Birds Fly "highways" Across U.S
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Binghamton University is studying how migratory birds respond to environmental changes over time. This year, Anne Clark and her colleagues launched a new research project to compile a decades of data on red-winged blackbirds and climate change. Some might make a short trek from New York to Pennsylvania, whereas others might travel thousands of miles.

articles.title: Vanuatu's Climate Minister: 'We Are Already Past Adaptation'
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Vanuatu's Climate Minister Ralph Regenvanu discusses the ICJ climate ruling, Climate Week NY, the Loss and Damage Fund, and what is at stake for Pacific Island nations. He also discusses the loss and damage fund and the Pacific Islands' role in climate change.

articles.title: Climate change to badly hit low-income earners, says ILO report
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: Climate change will affect 71 per cent of workers in 2024, according to ILO. It will also lead to productivity losses and a vulnerable population will bear the brunt.   Â. Â  ilyo.org/climate-change.uk

articles.title: Age, location determine climate risk: UN-backed study warns of unequal impact
articles.author: Anisha Ghosh
articles.summary: IIT Kharagpur study shows that climate change is not affecting everyone equally and extreme weather events impact people differently based on their age and location. Children and working-age adults in Asia and Africa will face the highest risks. The elderly in Europe, North America, and Australia will suffer the most. Europe is expected to have the highest exposure levels for seniors globally.

articles.title: Albanese calls for global action amid US isolationism
articles.author: Jacob Shteyman
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese has urged the world's nations to co-operate on climate change and peacekeeping. He warned that the US can't be relied on to uphold the international rules-based order on its own and called on it to do more to help the world.

articles.title: A new festival is flying in for bird lovers
articles.author: Eva Kolimar
articles.summary: The Far Eastern Curlew is listed as critically endangered under Australia's Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act. Over the summer, an estimated 73 per cent of the global curlew population lives in Australia. While in Port Hacking, the birds must feed undisturbed to build the strength needed for their return flight.

articles.title: Australia is not alone in embracing wind and solar, and we are certainly not way out front
articles.summary: It's common to say that Australia is out of step with the rest of the world with its 2035 commitment. Most countries are moving in the same direction at a greater or lesser speed. China gets 22% of its electricity from wind and solar. Thermal coal exports have been flat for 8 years.

articles.title: Ragasa: Hong Kong & China Hit by Powerful Typhoon
articles.summary: Super Typhoon Ragasa devastated Taiwan, the Philippines, and Hong Kong, killing 24 people and causing billions of dollars worth of damage. The increasing intensity of tropical cyclones is the result of climate change. The IPCC's Special Report on 1.5°C Warming details the link between rising global temperatures and more extreme weather events. Several key trends are likely to shape the future of typhoon risk.

articles.title: Anthony Albanese on collision course with Trump as he delivers radically different UN address
articles.author: MAX AITCHISON
articles.summary: Anthony Albanese delivered his inaugural address to the UN General Assembly on Thursday. He called for Australia to be given a seat on the UN's powerful security council. Donald Trump has called climate change a hoax and accused countries that recognised Palestine of emboldening Hamas.

articles.title: Early warning systems critical for disaster response
articles.summary: Song Shanyun, deputy director of the China Meteorological Administration, spoke to Outlook Weekly news magazine about climate change and climate change adaptation in China. Song believes climate security needs to be incorporated into the core framework of the national security system to prevent and address climate risks.

articles.title: ‘I worry about the future of my daughter': the ‘silent majority' who care about the ...
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: 80-89% of the world's population wants to see climate action. Readers share their ideas on how to make their voices heard on climate change issues with CNN. Readers are part of the 80- 89% of population who want to see action on climate.

articles.title: Climate Justice for Coastal Communities
articles.author: Muhammad Umar
articles.summary: Pakistan has a coastline of 1001 km with an Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of 240,000 sq km and an Extended Continental Shelf (CS) of 50,000sq km. The average rise of sea level is 3.6 mm per year, whereas Karachi's coastal sea level has risen 1.1 mm in the last year. 60-90% of fish stocks have been overexploited, and almost 40-70% of species have gone extinct. The Indus delta is one of the largest in the world and a major fish breeding source. More than 10% of the population depends heavily on marine life for their livelihoods. Pakistan's National Climate

articles.title: America's blame game over Canada's wildfire smoke misses the point, experts say
articles.author: BBC News
articles.summary: US officials blame Canada for not doing enough to stop its wildfire smoke from wafting south. Climate experts say it's not so simple and it takes more than one thing to stop a wildfire smoke.    i.e. the presence of climate change.

articles.title: Age, location determine climate risk: UN-backed study warns of unequal impact
articles.author: Indian Express
articles.summary: By using climate data and demographic data, the study will be able to predict future trends in the climate and demographic information. It will be based on the data from the Climate Change Institute and the Demographic Institute. It is based on data from both the CIMIT and Demographics Institute.

articles.title: Study links Arctic chemistry shift to ancient heatwave
articles.author: 李姿仪
articles.summary: A Chinese-led research team has shed new light on how the Arctic Ocean may have intensified one of Earth's most dramatic warming episodes 56 million years ago. The study focuses on the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum (PETM), a period of extreme heat and ocean acidification. The Arctic's chemical balance was a key player.

articles.title: Vero Beach won't be Key West, but airport? Growth hits Sebastian; Kirk fallout
articles.author: TCPalm
articles.summary: How southwest Port St. Lucie, Florida, evolved over nearly four decades. Vero Beach, Sebastian face concerns over development, airport expansion and traffic. Martin County teacher's removal over social media comments has sparked a debate on one in the chamber.

articles.title: Australia on track for third-largest wheat harvest, record barley crop
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Australia is on track to reap its third-biggest wheat harvest and its largest ever barley crop this year, according to the agriculture minister.      Â   in this year's barley crop is expected to be the largest in its history.

articles.title: 30C warming above South Pole flips Australia's spring weather forecast
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Temperatures above Antarctica have risen by 30C. It's a rare event that could flip Australia's spring weather for months. It could change the weather in Australia for several months.   Â      in Australia's winter.

articles.title: Registration open for 2025 Alaska Invasive Species Workshop (University of Alaska Fairbanks)
articles.author: Public Technologies

articles.title: Zambia launches early warning initiative against climate-related disasters
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: Zambia on Thursday launched an initiative aimed at preparing communities to protect themselves against the increasing risks of climate-related disasters. The Early Warning for All Initiative is a global effort championed by the United Nations to ensure that by 2027, everyone on the planet is covered by the UN's climate action plan.

articles.title: Caution – deer crossing (Hertfordshire County Council)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The number of fallow deer in the UK is at some of the highest levels recorded. Fallow deer are unpredictable and can travel several miles a day in search of a mate, crossing roads. Road users are reminded to take extra care this autumn. (Last updated on 25 Sep 2025.

articles.title: Millions of birds fly 'highways' across US—and their migration routes are breaking down

articles.title: Hot air: on U.S. President Donald Trump's rant against climate change science

articles.author: MENA FN

articles.author: MENA FN

articles.title: Italy and Spain Send Navy Ships to Protect Gaza Flotilla

articles.title: One year after Helene, football is an outlet as Owen, Asheville Christian recover
articles.author: Citizen Times

articles.title: Study links Arctic chemistry shift to ancient heatwave
articles.author: China Daily
articles.summary: The Arctic Ocean may have intensified one of Earth's most dramatic warming episodes 56 million years ago. The discovery could carry a warning for today's climate. The study was led by Zhang Yige of the Chinese Academy of Sciences' Guangzhou Institute of Science.

articles.title: Global 'Noahʻs Ark' initiative underway to safeguard coral reefs

articles.title: Feeling Green? NY Times Nauseous Over Trump's Rebuke of Climate Hysteria at UN
articles.author: Joseph Vazquez

articles.title: China moving away from fossil fuels sends 'strong signal'
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Erin Sikorsky of the Center for Climate and Security explains why China saying it's moving away from fossil fuels is significant, after Trump denied climate change at the UN and China's decision to move away from Fossil Fuels is significant as well.
